channel.title: EOFucks Up

item.title: EOFucks Up
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

frank_:

because the console input isnt available for reading until you hit enter

old topic, but I have found the answer right herr: http://www.daniweb.com/forums/thread276780.html

Read full topic

item.title: EOFucks Up
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:16, topic:333400”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=429807.msg3156158#msg3156158 date=1269068059]

ctrl D does on linux, in CMD it’s ctrl-break

oh also i remember that ctrl-Z works too, but i don’t remember what it does differently (If anything) from ctrl-break

In linux, ctrl-Z backgrounds a process (it keeps running, just in the background). Not sure what it does in windows.
[/quote]if by “keeps running” you mean is suspended, sure

i love how you made this same mistake the other day and i corrected you[/quote]if by me you mean someone else!!!

Read full topic

item.title: EOFucks Up
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Ctrl-Z worked, although only when it is the only character to be read (i.e., it has to be on a newline or at the end of the output line).

Ctrl-Break worked the same as Ctrl-C and just terminated the program on the stop.

Read full topic

item.title: EOFucks Up
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Simple C program (reading teh C bible to brush up my prgrmn sklz):

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    int chr;

    while ((chr = getchar()) != EOF) {
        putchar(chr);
    }
    return 0;
}

The echo part works, but getchar seems to never return EOF and the programs neva eva terminates. If it matters, I am using Command Prompt because I am icky.

Read full topic
